Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Hi Carmel & husband! Very sorry about "The News." Now Stop Reading this for a moment and go back to Pratoman's response and read his 2nd line out loud 3 times (you are entitled to click your heals each time as well)!!! Now is the time to relax, stay calm and start building an action plan. MF Thank you for this. I like the steps you have outlined. I like having something specific that I can do. I have a lot of experience in advocating for family members as they've been patients. I know how to do that. I've kept the notebook, asked the questions, written down the answers, filed the medical reports, tracked appointments and prescriptions. I've also learned when to overrule the patient and, for instance, call the dang ambulance already no matter how much they protest. I'm a strong advocate. I needed to know where to start. Thank you again.
Posts.Signature: My 57-year-old husband was diagnosed with aggressive prostate cancer March 31, 2017 (Previous biopsy 2015 did not detect cancer) 3/2017: PSA 21. Fusion biopsy; two ROI, 16 cores; Stage T1, Gleason score 4+5 = 9 4/2017: Bone scan and CT scan both clear. No evidence of cancer in bones or lymph nodes 6/2017: DaVinci robotic prostatectomy; biopsy during surgery did not show cancer outside the prostate
Posts.Title: My husband was diagnosed last night. This doesn't feel real. What should I do?

Posts.Content: My husband had a negative 12-sample biopsy two years ago. His PSA numbers continued to rise. Three weeks ago he had an MRI which showed two 'Regions of Interest.' That image was overlaid on the screen for his 16-sample biopsy this week. The doctor called last night reporting cancer in both ROIs as well as in another random sample. He called the cancer 'aggressive.' This can't really be happening, can it? We are both dealing with all kinds of emotions. On the surface I am calm and supportive and reassuring. Inside I am panicked and scared and on the edge of tears every moment. I don't even know what to do. Please help me.
Posts.Title: My husband was diagnosed last night. This doesn't feel real. What should I do?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman Carmel, sorry to hear this. First thing you need to know - your husband is not going to die of Prostate Cancer any time soon. Focus on that. Thank you so much for your reply. I read this sentence several times, talking myself down, and it helped me a lot. I hadn't realized that this is what I was thinking. It's actually what we both were thinking. I am now telling myself and my husband that his prostate cancer is just "a bump in the road." Originally Posted by Pratoman Second thing, get a copy of the pathology report. It would help us help you (as layman, but as guys who've been there, and done the research), if you could create a signature in your profile with the pathology facts... Gleason score, PSA, , # of positive cores, % of each core positive, etc We will get a copy of the pathology report this week. I don't have all the figures yet to put in a signature line, but my husband told me the Gleason score is 9. (Yikes.) Originally Posted by Pratoman Getting educated will give you and your husband a sense of control. My husband has been reading up on prostate cancer for several months. I've apparently been in a state of denial. I need to catch up. Thank you again for your kind and thoughtful response.
